questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room after accidentally ingesting a small plastic bead. Chest radiography reveals a radiopaque object in the right lower lobe. The bead is suspected to be causing near complete occlusion of one of the right lower lobe bronchioles. Which of the following physiological changes will most likely take place in the affected portions of the lung?

choices.text: Decreased pulmonary arteriolar smooth muscle tone

questions.solution:
This patient ingested a plastic bead that became lodged in one of the right lower lobe bronchioles. The affected portions of the lung will have decreased ventilation as well as decreased alveolar and arteriolar air pressure. These changes will ultimately lead to vasoconstriction and decreased perfusion.

Pulmonary blood flow is regulated to match alveolar ventilation and optimize oxygen exchange. Blood flow is controlled by altering arteriole resistance through adjusting arteriolar smooth muscle tone. If a region of the lung is poorly ventilated, there will be a decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen within the arterioles (PAO2) adjacent to that region. These changes in turn lead to hypoxic vasoconstriction and divert blood away from poorly ventilated regions of the lung.

In certain conditions, such as emphysema or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, there is chronic hypoxia and vasoconstriction. As a result, the right heart must generate increased pressures to pump blood through pulmonary circulation. Over time, these changes lead to pulmonary hypertension.

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased perfusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased perfusion:
Incorrect: The bead is causing significant occlusion of the affected bronchiole, leading to decreased ventilation. As a result, there will be a decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen within the alveoli (PAO2) and in the arteriole adjacent to the alveoli (PaO2). A decrease in PaO2 will cause hypoxic vasoconstriction and decreased perfusion, not increased perfusion.  
❌ Elevated V/Q ratio:
Incorrect: The obstructing bead will cause decreased ventilation (V) to the affected portions of the lung. As a result, the affected portions will have a decreased V/Q ratio.  
❌ Decreased pulmonary arteriolar smooth muscle tone:
Incorrect: The bead is causing significant occlusion of the affected bronchiole, leading to decreased ventilation. As a result, there will be a decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen within the alveoli (PAO2) and in the arteriole adjacent to the alveoli (PaO2). A decrease in PaO2 will cause hypoxic vasoconstriction and increased vascular smooth muscle tone.  
❌ Right ventricular hypertrophy:
Incorrect: Conditions such as emphysema can lead to chronic hypoxia. In turn, there will be persistent vasoconstriction. As a result, the right heart must generate increased pressures to pump blood through pulmonary circulation. Over time, these changes can lead to right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the structure and function of hemoglobin. He discovers that certain conditions favor the unloading of oxygen to tissues, as demonstrated in the graph below. Which of the following conditions favors this effect?

choices.text: Decreasing the partial pressure of CO2

questions.solution:
The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve reflects the saturation of hemoglobin at different partial pressures of oxygen. Several conditions may result in either a left or right curve shift. A rightward shift indicates increasing oxygen unloading to tissues, where certain conditions decrease hemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen. In contrast, a leftward shift means decreasing oxygen unloading to tissues and a relative increase in affinity for oxygen. Conditions associated with either shift are reflected in the tables above.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Increasing temperature:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decreasing temperature:
Incorrect: The decreasing temperature will result in a left shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, not a rightward shift.  
❌ Increasing the pH:
Incorrect: Increasing the pH will result in a left shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, not a rightward shift.  
❌ Decreasing the partial pressure of CO2:
Incorrect:  Decreasing the partial pressure of CO2 will result in a left shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, not a rightward shift.  
❌ Presence of carbon monoxide:
Incorrect:  The presence of carbon monoxide will result in a left shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin curve due to its higher affinity for hemoglobin when compared to oxygen.

questions.text: A researcher is studying respiratory physiology. Which of the following best describes the airway and intrapleural pressure at function residual capacity? Assume atmospheric pressure is zero.
questions.solution:
Lung compliance describes the distensibility of the respiratory system. It measures the change in lung volume for a given change in pressure.

The lung and chest walls together form a combined compliance system. The lungs exert an inwards pull and tend to collapse, whereas the chest wall exerts an outwards pull and has a tendency to expand.

At the functional residual capacity (FRC), which is the lung volume following passive exhalation, the inwards recoil of the lungs and outwards recoil of the chest wall are counterbalanced. In other words, the forces exerted by the chest wall and lungs are equal in magnitude but opposite in direction. Due to these opposing forces, the pressure within the pleural cavity is negative, preventing lung collapse and atelectasis.

Moreover, during FRC, the airway and alveolar pressure are equal to the atmospheric pressure, and there is no net airflow.  

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Functional residual capacity (FRC) describes the lung air volume following a passive exhalation. At FRC, the intra-airway pressure is equal to the atmospheric pressure. However, the intrapleural pressure remains negative (not positive) to prevent the collapse of the lungs.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Functional residual capacity (FRC) describes the volumes in the lungs following a passive exhalation. FRC corresponds to a resting volume where there is no net airflow. Hence, the intra-airway pressure is equal to the atmospheric pressure. Moreover, the intrapleural pressure is negative (not positive) to prevent the collapse of the lungs.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Functional residual capacity (FRC) describes the volumes in the lungs following a passive exhalation. FRC corresponds to a resting volume where there is no net airflow. Hence, the intra-airway pressure is equal to the atmospheric pressure.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Functional residual capacity (FRC) describes the volumes in the lungs following a passive exhalation. FRC corresponds to a resting volume where there is no net airflow. Hence, the intra-airway pressure is equal to the atmospheric pressure.

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying a protein found in human cells. They find that binding a substrate to this protein induces a change in shape, making it easier to bind additional substrate. Which of the following proteins are these researchers studying?
questions.solution:
Positive cooperativity means binding a substrate to a protein increases the ability to bind to an additional substrate. Hemoglobin is the primary protein found in red blood cells and is responsible for carrying oxygen throughout the body. Hemoglobin, a tetramer, houses four binding sites for oxygen, so a conformational change ensues when one oxygen molecule binds. Additional oxygen binding occurs with each additionally bound oxygen molecule.

This results in an oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve with a sigmoidal shape, as demonstrated in the graph below. This results in an oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve with a sigmoidal shape. This results in hemoglobin showing a steep, steady curve until plateauing—indicating complete saturation.  


Option Analysis

✅ Hemoglobin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Myoglobin:
Incorrect: Myoglobin is primarily located in the skeletal and cardiac muscle, which stores and facilitates intracellular O2 diffusion to the mitochondria. It does not demonstrate positive cooperativity.  
❌ Cytoglobin:
Incorrect: Cytoglobin is ubiquitously expressed in all tissues and has been related to collagen synthesis and protection against hypoxia. It does not demonstrate positive cooperativity.  
❌ Lipase:
Incorrect: Lipase is a pancreatic polypeptide that degrades triglycerides. However, it does not demonstrate positive cooperativity.  
❌ Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase:
Incorrect:  Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase is an example of an enzyme that demonstrates negative cooperativity. That is, as ligands bind to the protein, the protein's affinity for the ligand will decrease.

questions.text: A researcher is studying respiratory physiology. Which of the following conditions will most likely lead to an increase in lung compliance?
questions.solution:
Lung compliance describes the distensibility of the respiratory system. It measures the change in lung volume for a given change in pressure. The value is inversely released to lung stiffness or elastance (amount of elastic tissue present), with a stiffer lung or lung having more elastic tissue possessing lower compliance.

In general, conditions that decrease the amount of pulmonary elastic tissue (e.g., emphysema, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) will increase compliance. In contrast, conditions that increase pulmonary elastic tissue (e.g., pulmonary fibrosis, scarring), increase alveolar filling (e.g., pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome), or decrease pulmonary surfactant production (e.g., neonatal respiratory distress syndrome) will cause a decrease in compliance.  

Option Analysis

✅ Emphysema:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis will lead to increased lung stiffness and decreased compliance.  
❌ Guillain-Barre syndrome:
Incorrect: Guillain-Barre syndrome is an immune-mediated condition that can lead to respiratory muscle weakness. As a result, the condition will lead to decreased chest wall compliance. However, it would not affect lung compliance.  
❌ Acute respiratory distress syndrome:
Incorrect: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is characterized by alveolar injury and accumulation of exudative fluid within the airspaces. These changes will lead to increased lung stiffness and decreased lung compliance.  
❌ Lobar pneumonia:
Incorrect: Lobar pneumonia is characterized by the accumulation of exudative fluid within the alveoli. These changes will lead to increased lung stiffness and decreased lung compliance.

questions.text: A researcher is currently studying pulmonary circulation in both healthy adults and those with chronic lung disease. Which of the following is an example of perfusion-limited gas exchange?
questions.solution:
Normal gas exchange in the lung depends on diffusion and perfusion limitations. Diffusion-limited gas exchange is limited by the diffusion rate of the gas across the alveolar membrane. Examples include carbon monoxide or structural lung diseases such as COPD.

In contrast, perfusion-limited gas exchange results in partial pressures that equilibrate before blood leaves the alveolar capillaries, and gas exchange is dependent on the rate of blood flow through the capillary. A classic example is the administration of nitrous oxide, as this gas displays a rapid diffusion rate across the alveolar membrane and is not bound by hemoglobin. This results in a rapid rise of nitrous oxide within blood with only a minimal amount of the gas within an alveolus.

Option Analysis

✅ Administration of nitrous oxide:
Correct: See Main Explanation,  
❌ Emphysema:
Incorrect: In diffusion-limited gas exchange, the partial pressures between the alveolus and capillary do not equilibrate by the time blood reaches the end of the capillary. Diffusion-limited gas exchange is limited by the diffusion rate of the gas across the alveolar membrane. Examples include carbon monoxide or structural lung diseases such as COPD.  
❌ Pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: In diffusion-limited gas exchange, the partial pressures between the alveolus and capillary do not equilibrate by the time blood reaches the end of the capillary. Diffusion-limited gas exchange is limited by the diffusion rate of the gas across the alveolar membrane. Examples include carbon monoxide or structural lung diseases such as COPD.  
❌ Administration of carbon monoxide:
Incorrect: In diffusion-limited gas exchange, the partial pressures between the alveolus and capillary do not equilibrate by the time blood reaches the end of the capillary. Diffusion-limited gas exchange is limited by the diffusion rate of the gas across the alveolar membrane. Examples include carbon monoxide or structural lung diseases such as COPD.  
❌ Strenuous exercise:
Incorrect: Strenuous exercise is an example of diffusion-limited gas exchange, not perfusion-limited gas exchange.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of chronic exercise intolerance. He has to stop and catch his breath after walking two blocks or climbing 2 flights of stairs. The patient has a 55-pack-year smoking history. He undergoes pulmonary function testing and the results are shown below. Which of the following best represents the total volume of gas in this patient’s airways that does not participate in gas exchange?  

Calculated tidal volume (VT)  
500 mL
Upper airway volume  
80 mL
Conducting airway volume  
100 mL  
Inspired CO2 pressure (PICO2)  
1 mmHg  
Arterial CO2 pressure (PACO2)  
50 mmHg  
Expired CO2 pressure (PT)  
20 mmHg
questions.solution:
The total volume of gas in the airways that does not participate in gas exchange is referred to as physiologic dead space (VD). This patient with an extensive smoking history and exercise intolerance most likely has increased VD, which is calculated by Bohr’s equation as follows:

VD = VT (PACO2 - PT)/PACO2
VD = 500 (50 - 20/50)
VD = 500 (30/50)
VD = 500 (0.6)
VD = 300 mL

Physiologic dead space is the combination of anatomic dead space and alveolar dead space. Physiologic dead space is the volume of gas in the non-exchanging parts of the airway (e.g., upper airway, trachea, bronchi, bronchioles) whereas alveolar dead space is the volume of gas in the alveoli that does not exchange due to disruptions in alveolar anatomy, diffusion barrier, or blood vessels perfusing the alveoli (ventilation-perfusion, or V/Q mismatch).  

Option Analysis

❌ 180 mL:
Incorrect: This answer choice represents the anatomic dead space (upper airway + conducting airway) but does not account for all non-exchanging lung volume.  
✅ 300 mL:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 500 mL:
Incorrect: This value represents the tidal volume of the patient, which can be calculated from pulmonary function testing by subtracting total lung capacity (vital capacity + residual volume) from residual volumes (functional reserve capacity + inspiratory reserve volume).  
❌ 600 mL:
Incorrect: This answer choice does not represent the physiologic dead space.  
❌ 700 mL:
Incorrect: This answer choice does not represent the physiologic dead space.

questions.text: A researcher is studying oxygen content within blood among different disease processes. Which of the following diseases will result in increased oxygen content?
questions.solution:
Oxygen content refers to the amount of oxygen bound to hemoglobin plus the amount of oxygen dissolved in arterial blood. It is calculated via the equation below, where Hb = hemoglobin concentration, Sao2 = arterial O2 saturation, and PaO2 = partial pressure of O2 in arterial blood.

                       O2 content = (1.34 × Hb × Sao2) + (0.003 × PaO2)

Several conditions can result in either increased or decreased oxygen content dependent on how they affect the parameters of this equation. For example, anemia results in a decreased overall oxygen content due to decreases in hemoglobin content, whereas carbon monoxide poisoning results in decreased arterial oxygen saturation. Other conditions may result in increased total oxygen content, such as polycythemia, which increases the content of hemoglobin.  

Option Analysis

✅ Polycythemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Iron deficiency anemia:
Incorrect: Iron deficiency anemia results in a decreased amount of hemoglobin in red blood cells, a decreased oxygen-carrying capacity, and therefore a decreased amount of oxygen content.  
❌ Carbon monoxide poisoning:
Incorrect: Carbon monoxide poisoning results in decreased total oxygen content. This occurs secondary to the fact that CO has a much higher binding affinity for hemoglobin when compared to oxygen.  
❌ Hemorrhagic shock:
Incorrect: Like other forms of anemia, hemorrhagic shock results in a decreased oxygen-carrying capacity, and therefore a decreased amount of oxygen content.  
❌ Methemoglobinemia:
Incorrect:  Methemoglobinemia results in a decreased oxygen content due to its limited ability to both bind and offload oxygen to tissues.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the effects of exercise on a healthy human subject. The study participant is instructed to run on a treadmill, and various physiologic parameters will be studied. Which of the following physiologic parameters is most likely to be decreased in this subject several minutes after initiating exercise?
questions.solution:
During exercise, cardiac output, and pulmonary blood flow increases due to increased oxygen demand by the tissues while pulmonary vascular resistance decreases. In response to increased cardiac output, perfusion increases in the apex of each lung, increasing the available surface area for gas exchange; this increases the amount of the lung that is perfused, thereby These changes increase oxygen delivery to exercising tissues. As a result, there is increased lactic acid, and CO2 production, as well as increased temperature, which decreases the hemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen, thereby increasing its delivery to the tissues in need.



Option Analysis

❌ Ventilation rate:
Incorrect: Ventilation rate increases during exercise due to a number of factors: initially, psychological stimuli (anticipation of exercise) drives the increase in ventilatory rate, followed by the increased delivery of CO2 to the lungs following sustained exercise.  
❌ Pulmonary blood flow:
Incorrect: During exercise, cardiac output and pulmonary blood flow increases while pulmonary vascular resistance decreases. 
❌ CO2 production :
Incorrect: During exercise, CO2 production increases due to increased cellular respiration by the muscle tissues. 
✅ Physiologic dead space:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Cardiac output:
Incorrect: During exercise, cardiac output and pulmonary blood flow increases due to increased oxygen demand while pulmonary vascular resistance decreases.

questions.text: A researcher studies lung compliance and pressure-volume curves for the lung and chest wall in healthy adult patients. He discovers that lung inflation follows a different pressure-volume curve than lung deflation. Which of the following terms best describes this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Hysteresis refers to the phenomenon that lung inflation follows a different pressure-volume curve than lung deflation due to the effects of overcoming surface tension during inspiration. This results in a more considerable change in pleural pressure when compared to lung volume change, as depicted in the graph above. Hysteresis develops due to surfactant's effects on the lung's surface tension.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hysteresis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elastic recoil  :
Incorrect: Elastic recoil refers to the tendency for the lungs to collapse inward and the chest wall to spring outward.  
❌ Compliance:
Incorrect: Compliance refers to a change in lung volume for a given change in pressure.  Hysteresis, specifically, is the difference between expiratory and inspiratory compliance.  
❌ Minute ventilation  :
Incorrect: Minute ventilation refers to the total volume of gas entering the lungs per minute.  
❌ Alveolar ventilation:
Incorrect: Alveolar ventilation refers to the total volume of gas entering the alveoli each minute.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for a wellness visit. Past medical history is notable for cystic fibrosis. The patient has had several episodes of pneumonia over the past year and currently has a persistent cough with production of large quantities of viscous sputum. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 105/73 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Physical examination is notable for rhonchi throughout the bilateral lung fields. The patient is prescribed a medication that improves sputum clearance by disrupting disulfide bonds. Which of the following medications was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient with a history of cystic fibrosis and recurrent pulmonary infections was most likely prescribed N-acetylcysteine.    

N-acetylcysteine is a mucolytic that liquefies mucus and is often used in patients with thick secretions, such as those with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or cystic fibrosis. This medication works by disrupting disulfide bonds within the mucosal polypeptides. N-acetylcysteine can also be administered to treat acetaminophen overdose by regenerating glutathione and is used off-label as a prophylaxis against contrast-induced nephropathy.  

N-acetylcysteine may cause an anaphylactoid reaction when given intravenously and can also cause gastrointestinal side effects (e.g. nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, flatus).  

Option Analysis

❌ Dextromethorphan:
Incorrect: Dextromethorphan is an antitussive that acts by antagonizing NMDA glutamate receptors and additionally acts as a weak mu receptor antagonist. The medication can lead to cough suppression, which may further impair sputum clearance.  
❌ Phenylephrine:
Incorrect: Phenylephrine is an α-agonist that can be used as a nasal decongestant. This medication causes vasoconstriction and reduces mucosal edema. However, phenylephrine would not enhance sputum clearance by disrupting disulfide bonds.
❌ Guaifenesin:
Incorrect: Guaifenesin is an expectorant that increases mucosal clearance. It works by stimulating the production of hydrated respiratory secretions.  
❌ Dornase alfa:
Incorrect: Dornase alfa can assist with sputum clearance in patients with cystic fibrosis. This medication works by depolymerizing DNA within sputum and reducing its viscosity.   
✅ N-acetylcysteine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A male newborn is delivered prematurely at 26 weeks gestation, and he is found to be in severe respiratory distress. His mother did not receive any prenatal care during her pregnancy. His temperature is 36.0° C (96.8° F), pulse is 150/min, respirations are 50/min, and blood pressure is 80/55 mm Hg. Physical examination shows nasal flaring and subcostal retractions. A chest radiograph is obtained (see image below):  



 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons 

He is given artificial surfactant and supplemental oxygen, and the condition resolves within a few days. At a follow up appointment two weeks later, ophthalmoscopic examination shows neovascularization of the retina and slight retinal detachment. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's retinal findings?
questions.solution:
This premature male newborn, delivered at 26 weeks gestation, is presenting with severe respiratory distress associated with nasal flaring and subcostal retractions. These clinical features, along with his chest X-ray showing the classic ground glass appearance, indicates neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) due to surfactant deficiency. Surfactant is responsible for decreasing the alveolar surface tension. With insufficient surfactant levels, the surface tension of the alveoli becomes too high, leading to alveolar collapse. Surfactant production begins around 20 weeks of gestation but reaches sufficient level only at 35 weeks. Risk factors for NRDS include prematurity (as seen in this case), maternal diabetes, and C-section delivery.  

NRDS can be prevented in certain cases through maternal administration of corticosteroids prior to labor. In newborns with NRDS, treatment includes supplemental oxygen and administration of artificial surfactant. Supplemental oxygen, although crucial, can lead to several important complications, including retinopathy of prematurity, intraventricular hemorrhage, and bronchopulmonary dysplasia.

The pathogenesis of retinopathy of prematurity consists of two phases. During the hyperoxic phase (from oxygen supplementation), expression of the proangiogenic vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) is decreased, leading to endothelial cell apoptosis. With the return to room air oxygen levels, VEGF levels rebound, inducing rapid retinal vessel proliferation (neovascularization).This rapid neovascularization and scarring of the retina may cause retinal detachment and blindness.   

Option Analysis

❌ Maternal high blood glucose:
Incorrect: Maternal diabetes during pregnancy is associated with an increased risk for developing respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in the newborn; however, it is not the cause for retinopathy of prematurity.   
❌ Maternal alcohol use:
Incorrect: Maternal alcohol use during pregnancy can cause fetal alcohol syndrome, which is characterized by pre- and post-natal developmental delay, facial abnormalities, microcephaly, limb dislocation, and heart defects. It is not a cause of retinopathy of prematurity.  
❌ Maternal dexamethasone therapy:
Incorrect: Maternal corticosteroid therapy before labor helps facilitate fetal lung maturation. It is used to help prevent respiratory distress in premature infants. It is not a cause of retinopathy of prematurity.  
❌ Maternal indomethacin therapy:
Incorrect: Indomethacin therapy can be used to delay premature labor or to close a patent ductus arteriosus. It is not a cause of retinopathy of prematurity.  
✅ Neonatal oxygen therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Neonatal enzyme deficiency:
Incorrect: Disorders of galactose metabolism, such as classic galactosemia or galactokinase  deficiency, can lead to infantile cataracts due accumulation of toxic galactose products within the eye.  Disorders of galactose metabolism are not a cause of retinopathy of prematurity.

questions.text:
A 1-hour-old boy is being evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit for tachypnea, cyanosis, and nasal flaring. The infant was born at 30 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a mother who received inconsistent prenatal care. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 221/min, and respirations are 67/min. A chest x-ray is obtained, as detailed below. Which of the following would have been most helpful in predicting the development of this patient’s disease process?  



Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette is a premature infant who presents with signs of respiratory distress and a chest x-ray significant for ground glass opacities, low volumes, and a bell-shaped thorax, all of which is concerning for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, formerly referred to as hyaline membrane disease, is caused by developmental insufficiency of surfactant production and structural immaturity in the lungs. NRDS is characterized by tachypnea, tachycardia, chest wall retractions, expiratory grunting, nasal flaring, and cyanosis. Histopathology demonstrates layers of hyaline membrane and collapsed alveoli.  

Fetal testing for lung maturity is rarely performed, but it is sometimes indicated in semi-elective but medically indicated births <39 weeks, in order to predict the level of care that will be required. The lecithin–sphingomyelin ratio can be used to determine fetal lung maturity. Lecithin, a phospholipid, is a major component of pulmonary surfactant, and over time, it outweighs the amount of sphingomyelin present; maturity is likely when the ratio is greater than 2.    

Additional studies include the lamellar body count, another test used for the determination of fetal lung maturity. Pulmonary surfactant is made by type II alveolar cells, which start developing after 24 weeks' gestation and store surfactant in lamellar bodies; the lamellar body count, therefore, provides a representation of how much surfactant is present in fetal lungs. The test is performed via amniocentesis, in which a small amount of fluid is sampled from the amniotic sac surrounding the developing fetus.  

Option Analysis

❌ α-fetoprotein:
Incorrect: α-fetoprotein (AFP) is a screening test for a subset of developmental abnormalities; it is sampled from maternal blood or amniotic fluid in utero. Diseases in which α-fetoprotein is elevated include: omphalocele, neural tube defects, nonseminomatous germ cell tumors, ataxia telangiectasia, hepatocellular carcinoma/hepatoma, and metastatic cancers of the liver.  
❌ Inhibin A :
Incorrect: Inhibin A regulates gonadal stromal cell proliferation and reflects the size of granulosa-cell tumors. It is used as a marker for primary and recurrent gonadal stromal cell tumors.  
✅ Lecithin-sphingomyelin ratio:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Karyotype analysis:
Incorrect: A karyotype analysis can be used in the early detection of chromosomal disorders such as trisomy 21, 18, 13, and Turner syndrome. It is not useful in predicting neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.    
❌ Nuchal translucency screening  :
Incorrect: Nuchal translucency screening measures the thickness of the space at the back of the fetus’s neck. Abnormal measurements can confer an increased risk of Down syndrome, aneuploidy, and defects of the heart, abdominal wall, and skeleton. It is not implicated in screening for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

questions.text:
A 1-day-old boy is brought to the intensive care unit from the nursery due to increased work of breathing. The patient was born at 31 weeks to a mother with a history of multiple preterm deliveries, polysubstance abuse and HIV. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 215/min, respirations are 76/min, blood pressure is 60/41 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 85% on room air. Physical exam shows tachypnea, nasal flaring, and subcostal retractions. Administration of supplemental oxygen and positive pressure ventilation improve the patient's oxygen saturation to 95%. Blood glucose is 95 mg/dL. Chest x-ray and laboratory results are shown below:  

 

Reproduced from: Wikipedia
 
Laboratory value  Result 
Blood Gases, Serum 
pH  7.23 
 PCO2  55 mmHg 
 PO2  30 mmHg 
Which of the following best describes the etiology of this infant’s disease process?

choices.text: Insufficiency of a surface-active lipoprotein complex
Delayed resorption of fetal alveolar fluid

questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette is a premature infant who presents with signs of respiratory distress and a chest x-ray significant for ground glass opacities, low volumes, and a bell-shaped thorax concerning for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS), which is caused by an insufficiency of pulmonary surfactant. Surfactant allows the alveoli to remain open at end-expiration based on LaPlace's law, which states the pressure necessary to keep the sphere (alveoli) open is proportional to the surface tension and inversely proportional to the radius of a sphere.  

Surfactant normally reduces the alveolar surface tension, allowing for alveolar expansion and reducing the likelihood of alveolar collapse. Surfactant-deficient alveoli, therefore, have increased surface tension, leading to decreased compliance and distensibility. At end-expiration, surfactant allows the alveoli to remain open; however, when premature neonates who are deficient in alveolar surfactant begin to use their lungs, this increased surface tension results in an increased tendency for lung atelectasis, leading to a ventilation/perfusion mismatch, hypoxia, and clinical features of increased work of breathing (e.g., tachypnea, nasal flaring, and subcostal retractions).  

The most important risk factor for NRDS is preterm birth before 36 weeks gestation, as well as male gender. Other risk factors are primarily maternal and include gestational diabetes, cesarean section and maternal-fetal infection.    

Complications from neonatal respiratory distress syndrome can include barotrauma from positive pressure ventilation and ventilator-associated pneumonia. Unfortunately, NRDS is still the leading cause of death in infants <1 month old, and many patients die from persistent hypoxemia and associated metabolic derangements.  

Option Analysis

❌  Low levels of circulating blood glucose :
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia is a common cause of respiratory distress in the newborn and can also be associated with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS); however, the patient’s documented blood glucose is within normal limits.
❌ Transposition of the great vessels:
Incorrect: Transposition of the great vessels can cause respiratory distress and cyanosis in a neonate. However, the patient in this vignette responds to supplemental oxygen therapy, which does not commonly occur in patients with transposition of the great vessels.
❌ Viral inflammation of lung parenchyma:
Incorrect: While the patient in this vignette was born to an HIV-positive mother, HIV-associated pneumonia is unlikely to be the cause of respiratory distress in this premature neonate just 1 day after delivery. 
✅ Insufficiency of a surface-active lipoprotein complex:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Delayed resorption of fetal alveolar fluid :
Incorrect: This answer describes the proposed pathophysiology of transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN). Unlike NRDS, TTN is a self-limited condition that resolves spontaneously. It can be differentiated from NRDS by chest radiograph and the degree of supplemental oxygen support. Infants with TTN will require little to no oxygen, and a chest radiograph will often demonstrate increased lung volumes with flat diaphragms, mild cardiomegaly, and prominent vascular markings in a sunburst pattern originating at the hilum.

questions.text:
A 3-hour-old male newborn delivered at 28 weeks gestation is being evaluated for increased work of breathing. The patient was born to a mother with a history of diabetes and inconsistent prenatal care. His temperature is 38 °C (100.4°F), pulse is 219/min, respirations are 81/min, blood pressure is 64/41 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 87% on room air. Physical exam shows a mildly cyanotic infant with tachypnea, nasal flaring, and subcostal retractions. Auscultation demonstrates diminished breath sounds bilaterally.  A chest x-ray is shown below:  




Reproduced from: Radiopaedia 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette is a premature infant who presents with signs of respiratory distress and a chest x-ray significant for ground glass opacities, low volumes, and a bell-shaped thorax, all of which are concerning for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). This condition is caused by an insufficiency of pulmonary surfactant in developing lungs.  

The diagnosis of neonatal respiratory distress is based on clinical findings of progressive respiratory failure shortly after birth and chest radiography. Typically, chest radiographs for NRDS will demonstrate low lung volumes, diffuse reticulogranular ground glass appearance with air bronchograms, which stem from alveolar atelectasis side-by-side with aerated bronchi. The ground glass appearance typically results from surrounding pulmonary edema.    

Option Analysis

✅ Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transient tachypnea of the newborn:
Incorrect: Transient tachypnea of the newborn is a self-limited condition due to delayed resorption of alveolar fluid. It presents with an increased work of breathing minutes to hours after birth, but it requires little to no oxygen or ventilatory support. It can be differentiated by chest radiograph, which will typically demonstrate flattened diaphragms due to hyperinflation and mild pulmonary edema.  
❌ Bacterial pneumonia:
Incorrect: Neonatal bacterial pneumonia is a serious complication of early life and can be difficult to differentiate from NRDS due to similar radiographic findings. However, patients with neonatal bacterial pneumonia will typically have signs of sepsis, including lethargy, poor tone, tachycardia/bradycardia, or temperature instability.   
❌ Air-leak:
Incorrect: Barotrauma is a common complication of neonatal respiratory distress, usually from mechanical hyperventilation of poorly developed lungs in intubated patients. While the patient in this vignette has decreased breath sounds bilaterally, he has no evidence of a substantial pneumothorax on his chest x-ray, making this diagnosis less likely.   
❌ Tetralogy of fallot :
Incorrect: Cardiac anomalies should always remain in the differential diagnosis of a cyanotic neonate, including tetralogy of Fallot. However, patients with tetralogy of Fallot do not typically present immediately after birth. Additionally, patients will typically have an audible murmur on chest auscultation and a boot-shaped heart on chest radiograph.

questions.text: A newborn female is delivered at 30 weeks gestation and presents with expiratory grunting and cyanosis in the neonatal intensive care unit. Her temperature is 37.2°C (102.6°F), pulse is 225/min, and respirations are 85/min. Physical examination shows nasal flaring and chest wall retractions. Chest x-ray shows a "bell-shaped chest," a small, uniform right lower lobe infiltrate, and air-bronchograms. Which of the following interventions could have been used to prevent this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette, born at <36 weeks gestation, presents with respiratory distress and chest x-ray findings concerning for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, which is caused by developmental insufficiency of surfactant production and structural immaturity in the lungs. Antenatal corticosteroid therapy with intramuscular betamethasone is recommended in all pregnant women at 23-34 weeks gestation with increased risk of preterm delivery in the next seven days. When steroids are provided, they improve fetal lung compliance, volume, gas exchange, and surfactant production, and they enhance fetal lung antioxidant enzyme production. In addition, antenatal steroids have been shown to reduce the incidence of intraventricular hemorrhage, necrotizing enterocolitis, sepsis, and neonatal mortality by approximately 50 percent.  

Option Analysis

❌ Ribavirin:
Incorrect: Ribavirin is an antiviral agent used to treat respiratory syncytial virus or bronchiolitis. While patients with bronchopulmonary dysplasia are at an increased risk of developing bronchiolitis, ribavirin is not useful in the prevention of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.  
✅ Betamethasone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hepatitis B vaccine  :
Incorrect: The hepatitis B vaccine is a vaccine that prevents hepatitis B. The first dose is recommended within 24 hours of birth, with subsequent admission of additional doses during childhood. This patient’s presentation aligns with a different diagnosis.  
❌ Surface-active lipoprotein complex:
Incorrect: Exogenous surfactant (e.g. Survanta), or perfluorocarbon aerosol, can be used for the treatment of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). However, there is no role for administration of these compounds as a preventative strategy.
❌ Influenza vaccine  :
Incorrect: The influenza vaccines protect against influenza. A new version of the vaccine is developed twice a year, as the influenza virus rapidly changes, and it is administered to children > 6 months old.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent because of shortness of breath and chest tightness for the past hour. The patient appears tachypneic but is able to speak in full sentences. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for generalized anxiety disorder in the patient’s father. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. Pulmonary auscultation reveals diffuse wheezing bilaterally in all lung fields. After further evaluation, treatment with an inhaled medication is begun. The patient reports improvement in symptoms which was evident by increased flow rate on spirometry. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug used to manage this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)-mediated smooth muscle relaxation
Cell membrane stabilization of mast cells
Opening of calcium channels in smooth muscle cells

questions.solution:
This young patient’s presentation with acute shortness of breath and chest tightness, together with examination findings of diffuse wheezing, is consistent with airway bronchoconstriction, most likely due to an asthma attack. Administration of a bronchodilator, most likely a beta-2 (β2) agonist (e.g. albuterol) improved his symptoms.

Bronchodilation is accomplished by the inhalation of β2 agonists, which bind to the β2 adrenergic receptors on bronchial smooth muscle cells. This activates the enzyme adenylyl cyclase which leads to increased cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production that ultimately causes relaxation of the smooth muscle by reducing the concentration of intracellular calcium (Ca+2) ions.

It also stimulates the β2 receptors on mast cells and decreases the release of inflammatory mediators (e.g., leukotrienes and prostaglandins). This, in turn, decreases inflammation, swelling, and irritation in the respiratory tract.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)-mediated smooth muscle relaxation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cell membrane stabilization of mast cells:
Incorrect: Cromolyn sodium stabilizes the membrane of mast cells and prevents its degranulation (release of histamine and leukotrienes). Although it is one of the treatment options for the management of chronic asthma, it does not resolve acute asthmatic attacks.  
❌ Opening of calcium channels in smooth muscle cells:
Incorrect: The opening of calcium channels in smooth muscle cells by calcium agonists can worsen the condition by inducing bronchial smooth muscle contraction. Such drugs are contraindicated in acute asthma attacks.  
❌ Inhibition of eosinophil differentiation:
Incorrect: Anti-IL-5 monoclonal antibody (e.g.-Mepolizumab) therapy prevents eosinophil differentiation, maturation, activation, and survival mediated by IL-5 stimulation. It is only approved for use in patients with severe refractory asthma with serum eosinophil counts >150 cells/mcL.  
❌ Inhibition of eosinophil degranulation:
Incorrect: Corticosteroid administration can inhibit eosinophil degradation and it plays an important role in the management of acute asthma attacks. However, in contrast to beta-agonists, corticosteroids take several hours to days to take effect.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl with a history of asthma comes to the office with her parent for a follow-up visit. The patient’s symptoms are currently controlled with inhaled albuterol and low-dose inhaled budesonide. Past medical history is also notable for allergic rhinitis. The patient’s parent is worried about the side effects of glucocorticoids. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg. Physical examination is unremarkable. After a detailed discussion, the decision was made to stop glucocorticoids and start the patient on cromolyn. This drug acts by inhibiting which of the following?
questions.solution:
Bronchial constriction during asthma exacerbation begins with the release of several mediators from IgE-sensitized mast cells which include the leukotrienes (LTC4 and LTD4) and prostaglandin D2. The mast cell stabilizers, like cromolyn and nedocromil, inhibit the mast cell degranulation and prevent the release of prostaglandins and leukotrienes from mast cells, and are occasionally used to prevent asthma attacks. 

They are usually administered as an aerosol through an inhaler and are mostly safe and well-tolerated. Compared to inhaled steroids, mast cell stabilizers have a very short duration of action and are rarely used nowadays. Cromolyn and nedocromil may cause cough and irritation of the airway when given by aerosol. Rare instances of drug allergy have been reported.   

Option Analysis

✅ Mast cell degranulation :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Phospholipase A2 synthesis :
Incorrect: Cleavage of membrane phospholipids by phospholipase A2 leads to the formation of arachidonic acid, which in turn is converted into prostaglandins and leukotrienes. Phospholipase A2 is inhibited by corticosteroids (e.g., fluticasone and budesonide). 
❌ 5-lipoxygenase :
Incorrect: Zileuton, a 5-lipoxygenase inhibitor, blocks the conversion of arachidonic acid to leukotrienes. It is used for asthma prophylaxis and in preventing exercise or aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD). Cromolyn does not inhibit this enzyme. 
❌ Phosphodiesterase :
Incorrect: Theophylline is a methylxanthine that mainly inhibits the enzyme phosphodiesterase III (PDE-III), resulting in smooth muscle relaxation and consequent bronchodilation. Its use in asthma is limited by its adverse effects profile and narrow therapeutic window. 
❌ Cyclooxygenase  :
Incorrect: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) i.e. aspirin and nonselective NSAIDs, inhibit both cyclooxygenase isoforms (COX-1 and COX-2) and thereby decrease prostaglandin and thromboxane synthesis throughout the body. Cromolyn does not inhibit this enzyme.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl comes to the office of her pulmonologist with her parent after a recent asthma exacerbation that required hospitalization. The parent is concerned that the patient continues to wheeze and cough multiple nights per week. The patient takes multiple inhaled and systemic medications. The patient reports that she uses the restroom to urinate multiple times a day despite no change in her diet. A review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg. Physical examination reveals scattered expiratory wheezes in both lungs. Fingerstick glucose is 246 mg/dl. The physician stops the systemic corticosteroids and adds omalizumab to the treatment regimen. Which of the following is the most likely site of action of this new medication?
questions.solution:
This patient with polyuria and hyperglycemia is likely developing corticosteroid-induced diabetes. Moreover, her asthma control remains suboptimal. The physician recommended omalizumab to improve symptom control and reduce the burden of steroids in the patient's medication regimen. 

Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody that is administered by the subcutaneous route. It binds to the IgE antibodies in the bloodstream and blocks their binding to FcεR1 receptors on mast cells. This decreases the activation of mast cells and reduces the synthesis and release of inflammatory mediators like leukotrienes and prostaglandins.

It is an expensive medication and is typically reserved as one of the last treatment options. It is particularly effective in treating allergic asthma, which often presents with very high levels of IgE antibody. Side effects are usually mild and include susceptibility to infections and inflammation at the site of injection.   

Option Analysis

✅ A:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ B:
Incorrect: Cleavage of membrane phospholipids by phospholipase A2 leads to the formation of arachidonic acid, which in turn is converted into prostaglandins and leukotrienes. Phospholipase A2 is inhibited by corticosteroids (e.g., fluticasone, budesonide, etc.). 
❌ C:
Incorrect: Zileuton, a 5-lipoxygenase inhibitor, blocks the conversion of arachidonic acid to leukotrienes. It is used for asthma prophylaxis and in preventing exercise or aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD). Omalizumab does not affect this enzyme. 
❌ D:
Incorrect: Zafirlukast and montelukast are leukotriene receptor antagonists that are sometimes used in chronic asthma management. Omalizumab does not affect leukotriene receptors. 
❌ E:
Incorrect: The mast cell stabilizers (e.g., cromolyn and nedocromil) inhibit mast cell degranulation and prevent the release of prostaglandins and leukotrienes from mast cells. They are occasionally used to prevent asthma attacks. Omalizumab does not affect mast cell degranulation.

questions.text: A 15-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent for evaluation of a cough and increased work of breathing. The parent reports the patient has had a “barking” cough for the past two days, and today the patient seemed to be struggling to breathe. He has had low-grade fevers at home and has a sibling with similar symptoms. The patient does not have any significant past medical history and vaccines are up-to-date. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 102/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHH, respiratory rate is 32/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The patient has stridor at rest, moderate subcostal and intercostal retractions, and an audible barking cough. Based on this infant’s presentation and findings, a diagnosis is made, and he is treated with intramuscular dexamethasone and a single dose of racemic epinephrine. On reassessment 15 minutes later, the patient is resting comfortably in bed with a normal respiratory rate and without stridor. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Monitor for three hours, if no further stridor discharge home
Admit to the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU)
Discharge home with outpatient follow-up in two days
Administer additional racemic epinephrine and discharge home

questions.solution:
This 15-month-old boy presents with findings consistent with croup, including barking cough, stridor, and increased work of breathing. Patients with croup should receive dexamethasone. In patients with stridor at rest or moderate retractions, nebulized racemic epinephrine should also be given. Following the administration of racemic epinephrine, patients should be observed for three hours to see if symptoms recur. If there is no recurrence of symptoms, then patients can be discharged home.

Treatment of patients with croup depends on the severity of symptoms. Patients with mild croup can be treated with antipyretics, oral fluids, and oral dexamethasone as needed. Patients with moderate croup (stridor at rest and mild to moderate retractions but no or little distress or agitation) should receive oral or intramuscular dexamethasone and nebulized racemic epinephrine. Patients with severe croup (stridor at rest and marked retractions with agitation, lethargy, or cyanosis) should receive IV dexamethasone, nebulized racemic epinephrine, and possibly heliox therapy. All patients with croup should be provided with a cool mist. For children with ongoing severe symptoms, nebulized racemic epinephrine can be repeated every 15 to 20 minutes. Nebulized racemic epinephrine reduces airway edema. However, in some cases, rebound edema can occur, requiring further intervention. As such, patients should be monitored for at least 3 hours before being discharged. If symptoms recur, the patient should be admitted to the hospital and given humidified oxygen along with symptomatic care (e.g. cool mist treatments).
     

Option Analysis

✅ Monitor for three hours, if no further stridor discharge home:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Admit to the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU):
Incorrect: This patient is clinically improving following administration of oral dexamethasone and racemic epinephrine. Admission to the PICU is not needed at this time. If he continues to be stable without rebound symptoms, he can be monitored for a total of 3 hours and discharged home.
❌ Discharge home with outpatient follow-up in two days:
Incorrect: This patient requires several hours of monitoring before being discharged home, and if he develops recurrent stridor he can get additional doses of racemic epinephrine, and hospital admission would be required.
❌ Admit to the pediatric floor:
Incorrect: This patient needs several hours of monitoring before a disposition plan can be made. If this patient continues to improve without recurrent stridor, he can be discharged home.
❌ Administer additional racemic epinephrine and discharge home:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms have resolved and there is no further stridor on reassessment. Therefore, administration of additional racemic epinephrine is not necessary. The patient should be monitored for a total of 3 hours and if there is no recurrence of stridor he can be discharged home.

questions.text: A 6-month-old girl presents to the emergency department for evaluation of an episode of cyanosis and poor tone. The mother reports the patient was playing with toys when she suddenly became limp and "turned blue” for approximately 30 seconds. The patient had a pulse throughout the episode, and no cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) was delivered. The patient immediately returned to baseline and has been acting appropriately since the episode. The patient was born full term without complications and has no significant medical history. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 99/60 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, respiratory rate is 36/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is evaluated by the emergency room physician and is deemed appropriate for discharge home without further evaluation. Which of the following findings is most likely to have been found during physical examination?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with several clinical findings consistent with a brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE). The patient had an episode of cyanosis and hypotonia lasting less than one minute. After evaluation by the emergency room physician, the patient is deemed appropriate for discharge home without further workup. Therefore, the patient must be considered low-risk. Patients with low-risk features will have a normal physical examination at the time of evaluation. An open anterior fontanelle is appropriate for a patient who is 6 months old.

BRUEs are witnessed episodes during infancy, lasting less than one minute, that are characterized by cyanosis or pallor; absent, decreased, or irregular breathing; a marked change in muscle tone; or altered responsiveness; followed by a return to the infant’s baseline state of health. A BRUE is diagnosed when no underlying cause for these symptoms can be identified after a thorough history, physical examination, and occasionally lab work and further evaluation. Based on historical features and exam findings, infants who meet the criteria for a BRUE can be classified into high or low-risk categories.

When a BRUE is suspected, a careful history and physical examination should be performed to assess for high-risk BRUE features, the presence of which will guide further workup and management. High-risk features include age <60 days old, history of prematurity, more than one BRUE episode, episode >1 minute, and history of cardiopulmonary resuscitation by a medical provider. Patients are also considered high-risk if they have concerning historical features or physical examination findings such as, but not limited to, respiratory illness, access to medications, episodic vomiting or lethargy, congenital anomalies, bulging anterior fontanelle, or abnormal bruising. Patients with high-risk features should be further evaluated for targeted precipitating factors or physical examination findings that might suggest an underlying infectious process, inborn error of metabolism, cardiovascular anomaly, GERD/laryngospasm, epilepsy, or potential child abuse. Most patients with low-risk features will have a normal physical examination.    

Option Analysis

✅ Open anterior fontanelle:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Systolic murmur:
Incorrect: If a murmur is appreciated in a patient who presents after a brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE), hospital observation and further evaluation to rule-out a cardiac cause of the event is required 
❌ Ecchymosis on the face:
Incorrect: Signs of unexplained trauma such as bruising in atypical locations (e.g., scalp, face, ears) should raise concern for non-accidental trauma and abuse. These findings warrant hospital observation and further evaluation. 
❌ Repetitive predictable movements:
Incorrect: Repetitive predictable or stereotyped movements raise concern for seizure activity or other neurological disorder. These findings warrant hospital observation and further evaluation. 
❌ Cough:
Incorrect: At the time of the evaluation of a patient with a brief, resolved, unexplained event (BRUE), patients with upper respiratory symptoms should have further evaluation such as testing for pertussis and respiratory syncytial virus. This should be performed before discharging home.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent for a cough that has been present for one day and increased work of breathing that has developed over the past few hours. He does not have any significant past medical history and vaccines are up-to-date. He is currently enrolled in daycare and recently developed rhinorrhea. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 107/min, blood pressure is 107/60 mmHg, respiratory rate is 32/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The patient is awake and alert and is not complaining of pain. A barking cough is heard. He has stridor at rest with moderate subcostal retractions. There is no neck swelling. Oral examination reveals erythematous changes to the posterior pharynx and moist mucous membranes. Which of the following findings would most likely be seen on neck radiographs?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with several characteristic features of croup including a “seal-like” barking cough, stridor at rest, and subcostal retractions with a history (daycare) and symptoms (rhinorrhea and cough) of a viral upper respiratory infection. Croup can typically be diagnosed clinically, but x-rays may be performed to rule out other causes. The characteristic sign of croup on neck radiographs is the “steeple sign”, which indicates subglottic narrowing.

Both croup and epiglottitis can cause acute upper airway obstruction in children. Neck X-rays demonstrating the classic “thumb” sign, (reflective of the swollen epiglottis and surrounding structures) indicate epiglottitis. In cases of suspected epiglottitis, the diagnosis can be confirmed with direct visualization of a swollen epiglottis via laryngoscopy, but radiographs may be performed to rule out other conditions.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Subglottic narrowing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Enlarged epiglottis:
Incorrect: On soft tissue lateral x-rays of the neck in patients with epiglottitis, an enlarged epiglottis protruding from the anterior wall of the hypopharynx (the "thumb sign") can be seen. Patients with airway obstruction from epiglottitis are usually ill-appearing with stridor, high fever, and tripod positioning. This patient has features that are more characteristic of croup.
❌ Increased prevertebral depth:
Incorrect: On lateral neck x-rays in patients with retropharyngeal abscesses, increased prevertebral depth can be seen. These patients typically are ill-appearing and present with a “hot potato voice,” trismus (lockjaw), neck swelling, drooling, and cervical lymphadenopathy. This patient has features that are more characteristic of croup.
❌ Foreign body:
Incorrect: A foreign body may be seen on x-ray in patients with airway obstruction from ingestion of a foreign body. Patients can present with stridor that may mimic croup. However, symptoms are typically acute onset (cough and choking) and the incident may be witnessed. Associated signs and symptoms of infection as seen in this (e.g. low-grade temperature nasal congestion) will be absent.
❌ Subcutaneous emphysema:
Incorrect: Subcutaneous emphysema may be seen on x-rays in patients with esophageal perforation or mediastinitis. Patients with esophageal perforation typically have acute neck or chest pain and patients with mediastinitis typically have neck pain and fever. This patient has features that are more characteristic of croup.
